The demand for chicken is always high, being such a popular meal for many people as can be proved when you visit fast food joints in his area. Philip has been facing challenges accessing finances, but he feels relieved knowing that institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva are there to make his dream come true. Philip chose Juhudi Kilimo because the interest rate on their loans is low, and is on a reducing basis. Philip underwent training through Juhudi Kilimo, learning that saving is a continuous process in many microfinance institutions. Through the loan, Philip's income will increase and his life will permanently change, leading to better living conditions for his family and a positive impact to the community.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Makburat

texts.ru: Макбурат, 47 лет, замужем, имеет 4 детей школьного возраста. Образование-среднее, с 2004 года занимается сельским хозяйством- животноводством и полеводством. Дополнительно она шьет на заказ. Супруг и дети Макбурат помогают по хозяйству. На сегодняшний день в хозяйстве есть 2 коровы, 5 овец. На участке Макбурат есть большой сад, где она выращивает персики, черешню и яблоки. Экологически чистые фрукты пользуются большим спросом. Она обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку селитры и удобрений для обработки почвы, чтобы на будущий год получить хороший урожай, также Макбурат планирует приобрести корову. Доходы от кредита Макбурат планирует вложить в покупку новой швейной машинки, а также накопить на обучение ее детей.
texts.en: Makburat is 47 years old, married and has four school-age children. She has received secondary education. Since 2004 she has been engaged in farm work—raising livestock and growing produce. In addition, she takes in orders for sewing jobs. Makburat’s husband and children help her on the farm. At present Makburat has two cows and five sheep. She also has a large orchard, where she grows peaches, cherries and applies. Her environmentally clean fruits are in great demand. Makburat has applied to the Bai Tushum microfinance association for a loan in the amount of 100,000 KGS to buy niter [potassium nitrate] and fertilizers to cultivate her soil and obtain a good harvest next year. In addition, Makburat  plans to buy a cow. She plans to use the resulting revenues to buy a new sewing machine. She is also saving up for her children’s education.

loans.use: to purchase nitre and fertilizers for growing organic fruits as well as to buy one cow.

loans.name: Sokhorn's Group

texts.en:
An old woman living in Kampong Cham province, Sokhorn is 61 years old and a mother of six children. To support her family, she earns income via pork-selling and works as a construction worker to earn extra income. 

For Sokhorn, this is her second cycle with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner), and she has fully repaid her past loan. She leads a group of three members to get a new loan. As the group leader, she will use her loan to buy more pork to sell. She hopes that she can earn more income to upgrade her lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy more pork to sell.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina is 24 years old. She is friendly and hardworking. She operates a Zoona mobile money-transfer business, providing financial services to people in her mining town of Chingola. 

Selina has been running her business for four months now. She started running her own business after accessing a loan from Kiva. The loan helped her with her setup costs. She was able to purchase a small trading booth, which she now uses to serve customers. She also bought a mobile phone, which she uses to make her transactions. Selina is very grateful, she says without the loan from Kiva she would not have been able to start running her own business because she did not have enough cash to purchase a trading booth and a phone.

Selina takes pride in her Zoona business and strives to create an atmosphere that is welcoming to her customers and keeps them coming back. She enjoys the responsibility of running a successful small business. Selina’s challenge is that she operates her business with a minimum capital of $1000. This is not enough to service customers who want to transact larger amounts of money. This saddens her because she then loses out on profits. She has requested a Kiva loan to help her grow her business by increasing the funds that she uses to transact with her customers. This will help Selina earn more profits. 

Selina’s biggest dream is to go to college and study Business Administration. She is hopeful that once her business grows and becomes profitable, she can go back to school.

loans.use: To grow her business by increasing the funds that she uses to transact with her customers

loans.name: Sheryigit

texts.ru:
Шерйигит  родился 1968 году в кишлаке  Ниджани города Истаравшан Согдийской области в семье столяра плотника. Он женат и имеет троих детей. У него свой свой дом, который он построил сам. Он с десяти  лет занимается животноводством. Дополнительный доход  он получает работая столяром-плотником. Также он занимается дехканством.
В дехканском хозяйстве «Сайдило» он имеет 2,0 гектара земли,  из них 0,5 га виноград и на 1,0 гектаре выращивает корма для своего скота , 0,5 гектаре выращивает сельхозкультуры.
 Он хочет получить кредит для покупки скота.
Он заранее благодарит за поддержку МДО Арванд.
texts.en: Sheryigit was born in 1968 to a family of carpenters in Nidjani village, near the city Istaravshan in the Sogdiisky region. He is married and has three children. He has his own house, which he built himself, and has been involved in animal husbandry for ten years. He earns additional income as a carpenter. He also has 2.0 hectares of land in the "Saidilo" dekhan farm. He uses 0.5 hectares to plant grapes, 1.0 hectare to grow feed for cattle, and 0.5 hectares for other crops. He wants to get a loan to buy cattle. He thanks MDO Arvand in advance for the support.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Twegatte Group

texts.en:
The group is located in an urban area and is comprised of five members. They are involved in different activities which include: farming, retail, passion fruits farmers, produce traders and alcohol brewing.
Charles is a married man, aged 28 years.  He has two children.  He runs a retail business and also does farming as a side business.  He started his business in 2004 to improve his standard of living and also increase the family income. He acquired the loan to purchase more stock for the retail business.  His clients are people from nearby areas and residents. He hopes to build rentals in the next two years and also expand his retail business.
His challenge is limited capital and people taking long to pay their debts, which affects his cash flow. He is a trustworthy and hardworking man who appreciates the services lenders offer.

loans.use: To buy rice, corn flour, beans, soda, among other items for sale

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
In Ombo B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya, Jane has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Jane is a friendly member of the community with 5 children. Jane lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, a dirt floor, and an iron roof.

Ombo B village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Ka-Lazaro well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Jane’s family and the 30 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Jane has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. 

Jane volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help her community do away with water-borne diseases. There are also 3 other volunteer promoters from Jane's community who are also part of this loan; namely Judith, Patrick and Teresia.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Jane’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Lencer's Group

texts.en:
Lencer is 38 years old, has 3 children, and lives in Ojunju village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Ojunju village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from Ka-ber well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Lencer and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Lencer works as a peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Lencer and 3 other promoters in her community, including Brenda, Joshua, and Violet need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Lencer will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Lencer wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will help in killing germs.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Lencer's community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Carolyne's Group

texts.en:
Carolyne is 35 years old, has 4 children, and lives in Kodaa village in in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Carolyne works as a subsistence farmer for a living. Her community of Kodaa village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Carolyne is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected promoter by her village to help them obtain safe drinking water.

As a volunteer promoter, Carolyne represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using the chlorine dispenser. Carolyne and other promoters in her community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Carolyne wants to be a promoter because she believes that the chlorine will help them treat there water making it safe for drinking.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Carolyne’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Maliq

texts.en:
Maliq is 58, a married villager and the father of one who, at the age of 3, suffered from high fevers. Due to the fact that they could not go to the hospital, his health has been suffering a great deal ever since. 

Maliq and his family live in the very remote rural area of the eastern central part of the country. For the past 24 years, he’s been doing agriculture and livestock to earn a living for his family. As of this moment, he’s got one dairy cow and some teachers who come from the city to work in his village school buy the milk. Also he has 20 chickens in a henhouse and he sells the eggs to other villagers.  In addition to these, he’s got some agricultural land where he plants seasonal veggies, and also has some plum trees.

Being the caretaker of his son, he also receives about $99/month. Your financial help will be used to cover his pension contributions.

loans.use: to pay for his pension contributions as he is a caretaker of his sick son

loans.name: Bonking's Group

texts.en:
Bonking is 39 years old, has 5 children, and lives in Kamwana 3 village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Bonking works as a peasant farmer for a living. Where Bonking lives, his family and his community do not have access to safe drinking water. The community collects their water from Kapiyo well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. If Kamwana 3 community had a way to treat their water, they could improve the health of their community, keeping children at school and parents at work.

This is why Bonking is requesting a loan for a chlorine dispenser on behalf of his community. Bonking was elected to represent his community as a volunteer promoter. He is not only representing his community on Kiva, but also volunteers his time to educate the people in  Kamwana 3 village on the importance of safe water, and how to use the chlorine dispenser when they come to fetch water at their local water point. There are also 4 other volunteer promoters from this community, namely: Peter, Mary, Paul, and Pamela who are also part of this loan. The loan will be used for the installation of the dispensers and the initial supplies of chlorine. Bonking wants to be a promoter because he believes that the chlorine will help his community to consume safe water.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Bonking’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Lilian's Group

texts.en:
Lilian is 32 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Kamwana 1 village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Lilian works as a subsistence farmer for a living. Her community of Kamwana 1 village does not have access to clean water. The water that is used for drinking and cooking is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Lilian is a friendly member of the community, and has been elected as the dispenser promoter to help the community obtain safe water.

As a volunteer promoter, Lilian represents the community on Kiva’s website and educates the community and how to protect their families from unsafe drinking water by using the chlorine dispenser. Lilian and 4 other promoters in her community namely Melda, Jane, Suslia, and John need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Lilian wants to be a promoter because believes that the chlorine will help to reduce water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Lilian’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Kennedy's Group

texts.en:
Kennedy is 38 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Katombo B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Katombo B village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from David well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Kennedy and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Kennedy works as a peasant farmer, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Kennedy and other 4 promoters in his community, including Luce, Elizabeth, Eunice, and Ann need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Kennedy will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Kennedy wants to be a promoter because he believes that the chlorine will help in killing germs.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Kennedy’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Judith's Group

texts.en:
In Mirongo village in Ndhiwa, Kenya, Judith has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Judith is a friendly member of the community with 3 children. Judith lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, a dirt floor, and an iron roof.

Mirongo village does not have a piped water supply. Their collected water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Judith’s family and community using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Judith has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Judith volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help her community to keep their water safe and preventing water-borne diseases. There are also 4 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: namely Jacob, Harman, Nelson, and Caren.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Judith’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Hezrone's Group

texts.en:
Hezrone is 75 years old, has 2 children, and lives in Kaliech A village in Ndhiwa, Kenya. Kaliech A village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from the community well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Hezrone and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Hezrone works as a commercial farmer, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Hezrone and 2 other promoters in his community, Dan and Everline, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Hezrone will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Hezrone wants to be a promoter because he believes that the chlorine will help children not to miss school and the community work hard through less absenteeism.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Hezrone’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: David's Group

texts.en:
In Kakur B village in Ndhiwa, Kenya, David has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. David is a friendly member of the community with 6 children. David lives with his family in a house made of mud walls, a dirt floor, and an iron roof.

Kakur B village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from ka-Martin well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. David’s family and the 30 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

David has volunteered as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. David volunteered to be the promoter because he wants to help his community to kill germs that causes water-borne diseases. There are also 4 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are Linet, Godfrey, Daudi, and Mary forming part of this group loan.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that David’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en:
Josephine lives in a home with mud walls, a dirt floor, and an iron roof in Kodongo village in Ndhiwa, Kenya with her family. The community of Kodongo village collects their drinking water from Kodong well because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Kodongo’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Kodongo, 30 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Josephine has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are 4 other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: namely Hellen, Teresa, Dorine, and Moses.

Kodongo village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Josephine believes that the   chlorine will help the community to become strong to help them work, and will help prevent diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. Children will also not become absentees in school. 

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence borne diseases (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprints will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Josephine’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Las Triunfadoras Group

texts.es:
Este comité lleva por nombre Las Triunfadoras, está integrada por 20 mujeres activas, independientes y emprendedoras, mantienen el grupo unido y fortalecido. Son de la ciudad de Santaní, una zona aun en crecimiento, y que se encuentra muy lejos de la zona central del país.
La Sra. Lidia se destaca en este grupo por su emprendedurismo y esfuerzo por superarse, se desempeña como vendedora de ropas nuevas y seminuevas, sale y recorre por zonas aledañas a su casa, es un trabajo muy sacrificado que ella hace por su familia.
Ella pide este préstamo para poder comprar prendas varias para poder seguir con sus ventas como lo viene haciendo, de manera a poder continuar mejorando sus ingresos.
texts.en:
This committee is named “Las Triunfadoras” (The Triumphant Ones). It includes 20 active, independent, and enterprising women. They have been able to maintain a strong and unified group. The members are from the city of Santaní, an area that is in a period of growth despite being very far from the central part of the country.

Sra. Lidia stands out in this group for her entrepreneurship and her drive to succeed. She works as a seller of new and semi-new clothing. Lidia travels and makes sales in the surrounding districts near her house. Her work requires her to make many sacrifices on behalf of her family.

Lidia is requesting this loan in order to buy various types of clothes so that she can continue with her sales just as before. As a result, she can keep improving her earnings.

loans.use: to buy various types of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Marwa 1 Group

texts.en:
Marwa is the featured borrower for the Marwa 1 Group. She joined with her other group members to take this Al Majmoua loan because they have always been neighbors and friends.They are working hard to develop their businesses and their living at the same time.

Marwa is a 24-year-old married mother of two children. She has worked as a hairdresser from her house for four years to help her husband in covering the needs and expenses of their family.

Due to increasing living costs, Marwa's income is not enough anymore. Therefore, she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner, Al Majmoua, to pay her children's school tuition fees. She also wants to develop her business through buying necessary cosmetics to satisfy her customers' needs. She hopes to open her own beauty salon in the future. 

Marwa is the lady standing in the middle of the photo. With respect to the other group members, Zainab is the lady standing on the left, and Ghena is the lady standing on the right of the photo.

loans.use: to pay her children's school tuition fees and to buy necessary cosmetics.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be faithful. She operates a retail business where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in a strategic location, and her primary customers are individuals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough capital. 

She will use the Kes 80,000 loan to buy more stock of charcoal. 

Her business goal is to be the biggest charcoal supplier in the area within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be the best supplier of charcoal. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of charcoal

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is a married man. He has two children. He describes himself to be honest. He operates a transport business where he transports clients using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is located in a strategic location, and his primary customers are individuals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of enough capital. 

He will use the Kes 40,000 loan to buy another motorcycle. 

His business goal is to expand within five years. This is his third loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle

loans.name: Kiptoo

texts.en:
Kiptoo is a single man who describes himself as faithful. 

He operates a retail business where he sells tea, and he has been involved in this business for 2 years. His business is located in a favorable location and his primary customers are retailers. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stock of tea. His business goal is to have a wholesale business within 5 years. 

This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tea

loans.name: Lavura

texts.en: Lavura is 52 years old and lives in Yerevan, Armenia. She was very young when her husband died, but with her strong will and hard work, she raised her two sons and one daughter alone. Only her youngest son is unmarried and still lives with Lavura. She has no higher education, but she works at the bread factory as a baker. She works nearly every day and holidays to provide for her children and their families. Lavura has requested a loan of 250,000 AMD to undergo treatment to solve a dental problem.

loans.use: to undergo treatment on her teeth to solve her dental problem.

loans.name: Abadehemuka Group

texts.en:
Safina is a group leader who is 34 years old. She is married with 5 children between the ages of 1 and 15 years. The group name is called ABADAHEMUKA, which means “Don't disappoint” in English. 

She has a shop where she has been selling for 7 years. The group members sell different items and they believe they can change their business through the loan. With the loan, Safina would like to buy more sugar, rice and salt to sell. The profits from her business will be used to improve her standard of living and to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, rice and salt to sell.

loans.name: Mark

texts.en:
Mark is a 34-year-old police officer. He lives in a rented house with his wife and their 14-month-old son. Mark runs a business sending and receiving money in Zambia. He started the business to earn extra income to sufficiently provide for his family.

This is his second Kiva loan. His first loan helped him to get his business started. Today, Mark is taking out a second Kiva loan so that he can increase his working capital float and serve more customers. Mark's business is helping customers send and receive money throughout Zambia. His business is highly dependent on how much working capital float he has, in order to process customer transactions. Currently he does not have enough float to help all of his customers and he is constantly having to re-balance between his electronic balances and cash balances. This means that he cannot serve as many customers as he would like to and therefore loses out on profits. 

Mark is excited to continue offering mobile money services to his community. He says the support from Kiva has helped him start to grow his business and improve his quality of life. Mark would like to thank Kiva lenders for helping make his dream of running his own business a reality.

loans.use: to increase the money that he uses to serve customers on a daily basis, thus ensuring that he never has to turn away customers.

loans.name: Kombelwa

texts.en:
Kombelwa is 25 years old and she has a two-year-old daughter. She lives in the mining area of Chambeshi with her husband who works as an underground miner. Kombelwa runs her own Zoona mobile money transfer business.

Kombelwa is grateful to the Kiva lenders for their help in starting her business. She accessed her start-up loan, which enabled her to purchase a trading booth and a mobile phone. The loan also provided her with the funds needed to serve her customers. Today, Kombelwa says she feels empowered, as she is able to contribute to their household. Her business has also earned her respect from family members and people around her. This makes her very happy and gives her confidence. She is making good repayments on the loan that changed her life.

Kombelwa has requested a subsequent loan to help her grow her business. She says the business has not grown much and this is due to lack of money to increase her float levels ('float' is money that Kombelwa uses daily to serve customers who need to send and receive money). She explains that the business of mobile money is heavily reliant on how much float one has in the business. The more float she has, the larger payouts she can do, meaning she can earn higher commissions. 

Kombelwa would like to take this opportunity to thank her Kiva lenders for changing her life by lending her money to start her own business. She has even been able to buy a television set for her family with the profits earned from her business.

loans.use: To grow her mobile money business by serving more customers in her community who need financial services.

loans.name: Gzim

texts.en: Gzim is married and the father of two children, living in the southern part of Kosovo. In order to earn a living, he works very hard and long hours as a taxi driver. He has been in business for a long time now and is very known in the area for having a pleasant personality, being dependable and being professional. Gzim is very satisfied with his work and wants to be able to continue being a taxi driver in order to provide for his family and give his children a better education. He is requesting a loan in order to repair his vehicle and keep it in good, safe condition for his clients. Knowing that this is a Kiva loan, he wants to thank all of the lenders for their support.

loans.use: To repair his vehicle and keep it in good, safe condition for his clients

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en:
Felomina is a fish vendor with a 15-year-old son. She is 52 years old, married, and lives in Ormoc, Leyte, Philippines. She earns a living by selling fish, which she has been doing for five years.

Felomina is asking for a loan of 12,000 PHP to buy a larger variety of fish to sell. This will allow her to increase her income. In the coming months, she will manage her business well, which will allow her to pay her household expenses and start to repay her loan. She also will be able to continue to send her child to school. Felomina hopes this is the start of improved living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to buy a larger variety of fish to sell.

loans.name: Mwangi

texts.en:
Mwangi is a Kiva borrower. He has three children. He describes himself to be honest. He operates a farm where he grows crops and also keeps, sheep and cows. He has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is located in a fertile area, and his primary customers are large scale. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. 

He will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy farm inputs like seeds, animal feed, and fertilizer to enable him to increase production. 

His business goal is to have a large scale farm within five years. This is his fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs like seeds, animal feed, and fertilizer

loans.name: Peris

texts.en:
Peris is a married woman. She has one child. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a farm where she grows crops and also keeps cows. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a fertile area, and her primary customers are large scale. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. 

She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy farm inputs to enable her to increase production. Her business goal is to have a large scale farm within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a retail business where she sells maize, beans, and  millet. She has been involved in this business for six years. Her business is located in a strategic location. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. 

Gladys will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of cereals. 

Her business goal is to large within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cereals

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a widowed woman. She has 3 children with ages ranging from 8 to 15 years old. She describes herself as focused. 

Susan operates a retail business where she sells curtains, and she has been involved in this business for 6 years. Her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. 

She will use the KES 10,000 loan to buy more stock of curtains. Her business goal is to expand within 5 years, and she hopes that in the future she will be financially independent. 

This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of curtains

loans.name: Ganizani

texts.en:
Ganizani, age 29, runs his own Zoona mobile money transfer business in Kabwe, located in the central province of Zambia. With his first Kiva loan, Ganizani was able to purchase his trading booth, which he is using to serve his customers. This reduced his operational costs, as he does not have to pay rent. Ganizani is making good repayments on the loan.

Ganizani enjoys running his business because it gives him a chance to contribute positively to his community by offering a safe and easy way for people to send and receive money. He gets great satisfaction from seeing the smiles on his customer’s faces when they receive money successfully. Ganizani says his business is easy to use because his customers do not have to fill out any forms to transact with him.

Ganizani’s biggest challenge is that he does not have enough money in his business to satisfy all his customers. He is operating with a minimum capital of 1,500 USD. This puts Ganizani at a disadvantage as it limits the number of customers he can serve in a day. Ganizani is requesting a subsequent loan that he will use to continue to grow his existing business. This loan will be used to add to his working capital, so that he can successfully serve more customers who are looking to send and receive money from the trading booth. Being able to serve more customers will bring Ganizani additional profits that he can use to open a second outlet. He looks forward to expanding his business to improve the quality of life for his family and community.

loans.use: to grow his mobile money business to service more customers by providing a safe way to send and receive money through his shops

loans.name: Caesar

texts.en:
Caesar is 24 years old. He owns a Zoona mobile money transfers shop in Lusaka, the capital city of Zambia. He comes from a family of six and has a three-year-old son. Caesar describes his business as the service of sending and receiving money. He is very proud of the fact that he has been able to start his business from scratch. 

Before Caesar started his own business, he was an apprentice at a legal firm performing duties of a legal clerk. This gave Caesar confidence in himself and helped him to push through with his dream of opening his own business.  He enjoys running his business because he sees the impact it has on the community. People do not have to use their transport money to go into the central business area to access financial services. He also likes that it is a decent way to earn a living.

Caesar is requesting a Kiva loan to purchase the small trading booth that he currently uses to operate his business. The trading booth costs 1,000 USD and he will use the rest of the money from this loan to increase his float (the working capital that he uses to serve his customers). Right now, Casesar’s float is not enough because his shop is located in the area of Lusaka, where the demand is so high that he cannot satisfy all the customers. His loan will enable Caesar to serve more customers and earn more profits. He will use the profit from his loan to help pay for his studies and send money to his son. Caesar thanks Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy a Zoona-branded trading booth and provide essential funds to serve his customers

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.ru:
Гулнора уроженка города Душанбе-столицы Таджикистана. Ей 26 лет. Она разведена с мужем и жиевт с ребенком у мамы. Но Гулнора не считает себя матерю одиночкой, потому что у него прелестный сын, он ученик средней школы. Ее сын и мама являются самыми близкими людьми, ради них она живет на этом свете. Гулнора уже 9 месяцев занимается шитьем национальной одежды на заказ.
   Гулнора обратилась за кредитом, чтобы приобрести вышивальную машинку. Она собирается научиться вышивать и предоставлять услуги вышивальщицы. Она сможет зарабатывать больше создавая новые экономические возможности.
texts.en: Gulnora is a native of the city of Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan. She is 26 years old. She is divorced from her husband and lives with her child with her mother. However, Gulnora does not consider herself a single mother because she has a wonderful son, who is a secondary school student. Her son and mother are the closest people for her, and she lives in this world for them. Gulnora has been involved in sewing national clothing to-order for 9 months. Gulnora requested this loan to purchase an embroidery machine. She is planning to learn embroidery and provide these services as well. She will be able to earn more money by creating new economic opportunities.

loans.use: to purchase a new embroidery machine

loans.name: Reina Isabel

texts.es: Reina de 41 años de edad habita en vivienda propia al lado de su esposo y sus dos hijas de 18 y 14 años de edad y un varón de 8 años, por lo que se siente feliz de poder tener tan grandes a sus hijos. Ella es una mujer emprendedora que se gana la vida elaborando tamales de gallina, para luego recorrerlas calles de los cantones cercanos distribuyendo sus productos. Reina habita en una vivienda muy pequeña y humilde por lo que ella buscando tener mejores condiciones de vida ha decidido solicitar un crédito a FUSAI para comprar: cemento, arena, grava, ladrillo, hierro y pagar mano de obra para construir un cuarto en su vivienda, y así darle una mayor comodidad a su familia.
texts.en:
Reina, 41, lives in her own home with her husband and her two daughters, 18 and 14, and her son, 8.  She's happy to be able to have such grown-up children.  She's an enterprising woman who earns a living making chicken tamales to sell them in the streets in nearby cantons.

Reina lives in a very small and modest home, and she's looking to improve her living conditions.  She decided to ask FUSAI for a loan to buy cement, sand, gravel, bricks, and rebar, and to pay for labor to build a room on her house.  That way her family will be more comfortable.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, gravel, bricks, and rebar, and to pay for labor to build a room on her house

loans.name: Nuevo Amanecer De Putucusi Group

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal NUEVO AMANECER DE PUTUCUSI, el banco está ubicado en el distrito de Quellouno en la provincia de La Convención y departamento de Cusco.
La socia Isabel tiene 56 años de edad tiene 02 hijos y es conviviente, la socia alterna sus actividades diarias dedicándose al cultivo de frutas, la socia lleva buen tiempo con su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia cultiva naranjas, plátanos entre otros, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de semillas y abono.
La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
Los demás socios se dedican al cultivo de frutas, crianza de animales menores, agricultura.
Las socias que salen en la foto adjunta pidieron permiso para llegar tarde a la reunión por motivos de trabajo.
texts.en:
Isabel is a member of the Communal Bank “Nuevo Amanecer de Putucusi” (New Dawn of Putucusi) which is located in the District of Quellouno in La Convención Province, Department of Cusco. She is 56 years old, in a common-law relationship, and has two children. Isabel divides her time between her daily activities and her business of cultivating fruit. She has been in this business for a long time and is doing well thanks to the effort she puts forth each day into her work. Isabel grows oranges, bananas, and other types of fruit. She wants to keep working so that she can continue to support her family.

Isabel is requesting a loan in order to buy seeds and compost. She appreciates the loan that has been issued and promises to complete her payments according to the established terms.

The other members engage in businesses such as cultivating fruit, raising small animals, and farming. The members who appear in the smaller attached photo requested permission to arrive late to the meeting because of work reasons.

loans.use: to buy seeds and compost.

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin is 38 years old and is married with two children who are in high school. He has seven brothers and sisters. Benjamin runs his own Zoona mobile money transfer business in his hometown of Luanshya. He has been running his mobile money transfer business for two years. Benjamin has seen his business grow very steadily and is very happy with the progress. This will be his third loan from Kiva. His first loan helped him serve more customers by increasing his capital and he successfully repaid this loan. Benjamin then suffered a misfortune when his shop caught fire. He got a second loan to help him rebuild his business after the loss. This loan helped him get back on his feet and he was able to serve his customers and has since repaid this loan. Benjamin thanks Kiva lenders for their help. 

Benjamin has some day-to-day challenges that he encounters. He sometimes lacks adequate float (the working capital that he uses to serve his customers) to sustain huge money transfer transactions. Benjamin then has to turn customers away, which results in fewer commissions being earned. He has also wanted to grow his business by opening up more outlets within the region, but due to lack of capital, this has not been done. 

Benjamin is requesting a loan to open up another outlet to reach out to distant communities and increase his daily float to facilitate bigger payments. His loan will increase his revenue and help support his family financially. Benjamin is optimistic that his profit margins will increase and very soon he will save up enough money to send his children to college.

loans.use: to open up another outlet to reach out to distant communities and increase his daily float

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is a married man with three children. He describes himself as honest. He operates a farm where he grows crops and also keeps dairy cows. He has been involved in this business for six years. His business is located in a strategic place, and his primary customers buy large quantities of his output. He will use the 60,000 KES loan to buy farm inputs such as fertilizer and seeds to increase production of his farm. He hopes that in the future, he will have a large-scale business. This is his fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance bank, and the previous loans were repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to buy more farm inputs.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as fertilizer and seeds to increase production.

loans.name: Mayya

texts.ru: Ее зовут Майя. Ей 28 лет. Она проживает на районе под названием Дж.Руми. Этот район переименован не давно и назвали в честь великого персидского писателя Джалохиддини Руми. Майя замужем. Она хочет создать собственный устойчивый бизнес. Майя решила начать животноводческую деятельность, потому что климат Таджикистана вполне подходить для данной деятельности и благоприятно влияет на здоровый рост скотов. Майя твердо поставила себе цель и намерена начать выращивать скотов, как только она соберет надобную сумму денег. Майе не хватает не большой суммы для купли скотов для начала, но у нее есть коровник и корм для скотин. Вы можете поддержать Майю в ее начинаниях, поддержите ее!
texts.en: Her name is Mayya. She is 28 years old. She lives in the J. Rumy district. This district was recently renamed after the great Persian writer, Jalohiddini Rumy. Mayya is married. She wants to start her own, stable business. Mayya decided to start an animal husbandry business because Tajikistan's climate is quite suitable for this type of business and favorably contributes to the healthy livestock growth. Mayya set a firm goal for herself and intends to fatten up livestock as soon as she is able to come up with the necessary sum of money. Mayya is short a small sum to buy initial livestock, but she has a cowshed and livestock feed. You can support Mayya in her beginnings; please support her!

loans.use: to buy livestock and start her own animal husbandry business

loans.name: Shehab Group

texts.en:
Mona is the featured borrower for Shehab Group. She got together with the other group members to take this Al Majmoua loan because they have always been neighbors and friends. They are working hard to develop their businesses and improve their way of life at the same time.

Mona is a 24-year-old married Syrian mother of three children. Due to the low social and financial situations of her husband, she started working five years ago in agriculture to help her husband meet the needs and expenses of their family. Today, Mona is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to develop her business by investing in an agricultural tent which will increase her production and satisfy her customers. 

Mona is the first lady on the left of the photo. Fatima is the lady standing, and Donia is the first lady on the right of the photo.

loans.use: to buy an agricultural tent

loans.name: Mamlakat

texts.ru:
Мамлакат является 55-летней швеей. Она честная порядочная женщина, которая на протяжении 15 лет зарабатывает на жизнь предоставляя услуги швеи. Мамалакат вдова и живет вместе с сыном и невесткой в районе Спитамен. Сын ездит в Россию на заработки, а невестка помогает в деятельности свекрови.
Мамалакат сейчас хотела бы расширить свою швейную деятельность и приобрести еще одну швейную машинку, чтобы брать больше заказов и увеличить количество клиентов. Свою цель она собирается реализовать с помощью средств  кредита. Мамалакат надеется на финансовую поддержку, которая ей действительно необходима для развития деятельности.
texts.en: Mamlakat is a 55-year-old seamstress. She is an honest and decent woman, who has been earning a living for 15 years by providing seamstress services. Mamlakat is a widow and lives with her son and daughter-in-law in the Spitamen district. Her son travels to Russia for work, and daughter-in-law helps her with the business. Mamlakat currently wants to expand her sewing business and buy another sewing machine in order to accept more orders and attract more customers. She is planning to achieve her goal with the help of this loan. Mamlakat is relying on the financial support, which is truly necessary for her to develop her business.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine in order to expand her business

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a married woman with three children. For the past four years, she has operated a business selling water. Christine describes herself as God-fearing. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. 

Christine is requesting a 20,000 KES loan to buy a water tank to store water to sell. This will be her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Christine hopes that, in the future, she will expand business.

loans.use: buy a water tank to store water to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: invest in her business and continue the sales that permit her to maintain her children.

loans.name: Veronicah

texts.en:
Veronicah is a single woman. She describes herself as ambitious. 

She operates a retail business where she sells cereals. She has been involved in this business for 2 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are individuals. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy more cereal stock. 

Her business goal is to expand the business within 5 years. She hopes that, in the future, she will have a different type of business. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more cereal stock.

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is a married woman with three children. For the past six years, she has operated a tailoring business where she makes clothing. Harriet describes herself to be honest. Her business is located in a productive place and her primary customers are individuals. Harriet describes her biggest business challenge as the lack of enough capital. 

Harriet is requesting a 30,000 KES loan to buy more stock of tailoring materials. This will be her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Harriet successfully repaid her previous loan. Her business goal is to open another tailoring shop within five years.

loans.use: buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a  Kiva borrower. She has 2 children. She describes herself as courageous. 

She operates a M-pesa business where she offers mobile phone based money transfer services. She has been involved in this business for 1 years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are individuals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insecurity. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to add to her M-Pesa float. 

Her business goal is to expand her business within 5 years. She hopes, that in the future, she will own a big business. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to add to her M-Pesa float.

loans.name: Jose Gilberto

texts.es: José, tiene 38 años de edad, esta casado, tiene un hijo y vive con su familia en una aldea del municipio de Gracias, Lempira. Desde pequeño se ha dedicado a la agricultura junto a su familia y lleva 6 años de tener su propia finca de café, esta cosecha la vende en grano entero en el mercado local o intermediarios. El quiere mantener esta fuente de ingresos y ha decidido solicitar un préstamo por 10,000 Lempiras  para comprar abonos que necesita para fertilizar la finca y esperar buena cosecha. Su plan es sembrar mas café para incrementar la producción y los ingresos de la familia.
texts.en: José is 38 years old, married and has a son. He lives with his family in a village in the Gracias municipality in the Lempira district. He has worked in agriculture along with his family since he was a boy. He has owned his own coffee farm for 6 years and he is selling whole bean coffee from this year's harvest in the local market or to middlemen. He wants to maintain this source of income and has decided to ask for a loan of 10,000 Lempiras to purchase fertiliser for the farm and to therefore expect a good harvest. His plan is to plant more coffee and increase the production and income of his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertiliser for his coffee farm.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela is 32 years old. She describes herself as confident and self-driven. She is a mother of two girls ages 7 and 10. Angela has been running her business of sending and receiving money with Zoona for five years.

Angela has been able to successfully grow her business through the help from Kiva lenders. She has received and paid back 3 large loans, which helped her open more outlets and employ more young people from her community. Having access to the Kiva loans has also given Angela an adequate float of working capital in order to service her customers efficiently. Currently, Angela operates seven mobile money transfer outlets and employs 17 young women in Solwezi, Zambia. She is passionate about empowering young women to keep them from vices like prostitution, which is rife in the mining town of Solwezi.

Now that Angela has successfully paid back her three previous loans, she is requesting a new loan to continue growing her mobile money business. With this loan, she will be able to serve more customers in a community that needs financial services. Her dream is to keep expanding her business and employ more young women so that she can give them a chance to improve their lives, too.

Angela would like to let her Kiva lenders know how much her life has changed. She is empowered and is able to take care of her children and support her parents. She attributes her success to Zoona, Kiva, and a lot of hard work.

loans.use: To grow her mobile money business to serve more customers, providing a safe way to send and receive money and pay bills through her shops.

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 41 years old. She is married with 5 children aged between 6 and 21 years, all of whom go to school. 

She has a canteen and has been in business for 15 years. With this loan, she would like to buy more sugar and snakes to resell. 

The profits from the business will be used to improve her standard of living and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy more sugar and snakes to resell.

loans.name: Shahnoz

texts.ru:
33-летняя Шахноз живет в одном из самых теплых мест Таджикистана, в районе Шахритус, расположившийся на юге страны. Шахноз живет там вместе с тремя несовершеннолетними детьми и свекровью. Муж находится в России и работает там в качестве трудового мигранта. 
Шахноз решила поднять экономическое положени семьи. Для этого она собирается начать торговый бизнес. Шахноз рядом с домом открывает магазин продуктовых и хозяйственных товаров. Она уже на свои сбережения закупила малую часть товара и ей еще не хватает немного средств, чтобы заполнить полки магазина необходимыми товарами и открыть магазин. Шахноз с такой целью обратилась за кредитом. Она собирается приобрести качественные продукты питания и хозяйственные товары, в котором нуждаются ее односельчане. Благодаре кредиту Шахноз обеспечит себя работой, а жителей своего села необходимыми товарами. Поддержите ее в начинании бизнеса и улучшении ее экономического положения.
texts.en: 33-year-old Shahnoz lives in one of the warmest locations of Tajikistan - the Shahrituz district, situated in the south of the country. Shahnoz lives there together with her three underage children and mother-in-law. Her husband is in Russia and works there as a migrant worker. Shahnoz decided to lift her family's economic situation. To accomplish this, she is planning to start a retail business. Shahnoz is opening a food and household goods store near her house. She has already purchased a small inventory of merchandise with her savings and is short a small amount to fill the store shelves with the necessary goods and open the store. With this goal in mind, Shahnoz requested a loan. She is planning to purchase quality food products and household goods that her fellow village residents require. Thanks to this loan, Shahnoz will provide herself with work and village residents with necessary merchandise. Please support her in starting this business and improving her economic situation.

loans.use: to buy food products and household goods in order to open her own store

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es:
El espíritu de  superación  personal  es lo que motiva a María Auxiliadora a salir adelante. A sus 43 años de edad  cree fielmente que para la educación no existen límites. Su  humilde familia es su mayor afán y sin duda las persona que la apoyan incondicionalmente  en su sueño de adquirir su título y ejercer su carrera.  Es por esto que bajo sus condiciones solicita préstamo para los gastos que requieren la adquisición de su diploma y así acabar con los obstáculos que le impiden desarrollarse como una profesional.
La costura es su oficio y con esto ha logrado abastecer  a su familia en los últimos años, ella asegura que este préstamo aportara tanto a su desarrollo como al de su familia  ya que con su título en manos podrá lograr un trabajo competitivo y con ingresos más estables. Después de lograr su primera carrera Auxiliadora planea seguir estudiando y absorber más conocimientos para ser un maravilloso ejemplo a sus hijos y para aportar al avance de su país.
texts.en:
The spirit of self-improvement is what motivates Maria Auxiliadora to move forward. At 43 years of age, she truly believes that there are no limits when it comes to education. Her humble family is her biggest motivation, and, without a doubt, they are the ones who unconditionally support her dream of getting her degree and practicing her profession. It is because of this that she requests this loan to cover the expenses of obtaining her diploma and therefore overcoming the obstacles which have prevented her from developing as a professional.

Sewing is her trade, and by doing this work she has managed to to provide for her family in recent years. She guarantees that this loan will contribute to her development as well as that of her family, given that with her degree in hand, she will be able to get a more competitive job and a more stable income. 

After earning her first degree, Auxiliadora plans to keep studying and learning in order to set a great example for her children and to help her country advance.

loans.use: pay for the expenses of earning her diploma

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a married man. He has four children with ages ranging from 3 years to 10 years. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a retail business where he sells kerosene. 

George has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are individuals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be price fluctuations. He will use the Kes 15,000 loan to buy more stock of kerosene. His business goal is to expand his business within five years. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of kerosene

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David, a husband and father of four children, is a mixed small-scale farmer based in the remote village of Songhor, Nandi Hills. He has been practicing agricultural business for the past nine years and has never looked back. For a living, David sells milk and food products from his farm at the local market. He enjoys seeing clients coming back for more of his products and he really feels satisfied. 

Although David has been making profits through farming, he has always wanted to do poultry farming. The main challenge he has encountered is a lack of funds to get his business off the ground. David is seeking a loan to buy quality breeds of poultry. Poultry farming is a very profitable business venture in Nandi Hills and is a business that can be done on a part-time basis to earn extra income. 

David does not worry too much about competition because the market for poultry products is good - chicken is a popular meal for many people and this can be seen if you visit any fast food joint. With this loan, David is confident that his income will increase and this will allow a permanent change in his life. He plans to buy different breeds of broilers and layers and will be selling eggs and meat to the local market and other major markets in Kenya. He also plans to start breeding, which will help increase the number of poultry on his farm. Other than profits from selling eggs, poultry feathers, and poultry meat, David will also benefit from using the poultry manure, which is an excellent source of nutrients for his farm. Through this loan, he will assure his large family of a secure future and improved living conditions.

David dreams of having a sustainable poultry business in the future with a good flow of customers, and of generating work. Help a young entrepreneur with a creative mind and big dreams!

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a Kiva borrower. She has five children. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a dairy farm. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are individuals. 

Agnes describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy animal feed. Her business goal is to expand within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be successful. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy animal feed

loans.name: Everline

texts.en:
Everline is a married woman. She has two children. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a retail business where she sells bread, tomatoes, cereals, and potato chips. She has been involved in this business for one year. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are individuals. 

Everline describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of finances. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy more stock of tomatoes, bread,  and potato chips. She hopes that in the future, she will own a large hotel. This is her first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tomatoes, bread, and potato chips

loans.name: Seiil

texts.en:
Seiil is a freshman at the American University of Central Asia (AUCA) in the Department of Journalism and Mass Communication. Here is her story:

“From childhood, I had a dream to study at AUCA. Everybody was telling [me] that just students from rich families study there, and I lost my hope. I applied to AUCA and learned about the Kiva loan, which surprised me, and I understood that it is my fortune.

My English teacher, Valeria, was my inspiration at school. She is an alumna of AUCA and wanted us to enter it. She used to tell us that AUCA offers a dual degree with Bard College, [and] opens doors for talented students from around the world with the passion to learn and transform the world. I loved to take her classes and my life changed 100%. She taught us not only the grammar and punctuation of English, but we used to discuss the difficult topics like DNA, international terrorism, education in Europe and America, global population increasing and so on. 

Thanks to her classes I have improved my English. I even participated in English Olympiads and took good places, what assured me [to] never give up my dream: AUCA. 

I studied hard and successfully passed AUCA entrance exams. My mother was glad for my achievements, but worried about my tuition fee. As we are three people in my family- my mother, my sister and me - my mother is the only breadwinner in it. She worked full years without vacations, just to support us and give a good education. Unfortunately, several months ago she lost her job, which made my family’s financial situation worse. 

I hope Kiva lenders will review my situation and will give me a chance to be the best student of AUCA."

loans.use: to pay for her higher education

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a 24-year-old housewife who has two children. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. Amina’s husband owns a vegetable shop in the market which is the only source of income for the family. Her husband sells fresh vegetables of different kinds from his shop. He is interested in offering more variety of produce to his customers to help increase his net income and savings. However, due to the lack of money, this is difficult. 

Amina is requesting a loan from the Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan to help her husband to purchase a greater variety of vegetables from the field to sell in the market at a profitable price. She and her husband will use the profit from her loan to expand their business in the future. Amina is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy fresh vegetables for her husband's shop

loans.name: Gulbara

texts.ru: Гульбара, 52 года, вдова, мать 3 детей, они взрослые и самостоятельные. У Гульбары - среднее образование, уже 14 лет занимается животноводством. Стартовав с 10,000 сом (KGS), благодаря упорному труду, на сегодняшний день у Гульбары в хозяйстве есть 4 коровы и 18 овец. Ежемесячный доход составляет до 15,000 сом (KGS), этих средств не хватает на достойную жизнь и содержание семьи. Так как животноводство- единственный источник дохода семьи Гульбары, она в целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, обратилась в Банк "Бай-Тушум" за кредитом в сумме 150,000 сом (KGS) для покупки 2 дойных коров с телятами. Доходы от кредита Гульбара хочет вложить в приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на свадьбу сына.
texts.en: Gulbara is 52 years old, a widow and a mother of 3 children. all of whom are grown and independent. Gulbara has a secondary education and has been involved in animal husbandry for 14 years. Having started with 10,000 som (KGS), today, thanks to her hard work, Gulbara has 4 cows and 18 sheep. Her monthly income amounts up to 15,000 som (KGS), but this money is not enough for a decent life and supporting a family. Because the animal husbandry business provides the sole source of income for Gulbara's family, she requested a loan in the amount of 150,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy 2 dairy cows with calves in order to further develop her business. Gulbara plans to invest the earnings from the loan into increasing her livestock headcount and saving money for her son's wedding.

loans.use: to buy 2 dairy cows with calves in order to increase her livestock headcount and grow her income

loans.name: Ra'nogul

texts.ru: На фотографии запечатлена женщина по имени Раъногул. Ей 42 года. Она вдова. Раъногул живет вместе с детьми в городе Курган-Тюбе. Она мать прекрасных дочек. Раъногул 10 лет работает в больнице и параллельно в свободное время от работы занимается торговой деятельностью. Торговую деятельность она начала после смерти мужа, 4 года назад. Раъногул пережила смерть мужа и нашла в себе силы не отчаиваться. Она решила обратиться за кредитом для купли заколок, резинок и других аксессуаров для волос, чтобы расширить торговую деятельность и увеличить доход, и для того, чтобы ее дочки не знали нужду. Они являются стимулов в жизни Раъногул и мотивацией для продолжения жизни. Поддержите Раъногул
texts.en: This photograph pictures a woman by the name of Ra'nogul. She is 42 years old. She is a widow. Ra'nogul lives with her children in the town of Qurgan-Tube. She is a mother of beautiful daughters. Ra'nogul has been working at a hospital for 10 years and parallel to this, in her free time, is involved in a retail business. She started the retail business after her husband's death 4 years ago. Ra'nogul survived her husband's death and found strength in herself not to despair. She decided to request this loan to buy hairpins, bands and other hair accessories in order to expand her retail business and increase her income, and to make sure that her daughters were never in need. They are the stimulus in Ra'nogul's life and motivation to continue living. Please support Ra'nogul.

loans.use: to buy hairpins, bands and other hair accessories in order to expand her retail business and increase her income

loans.name: Rosa Amalia

texts.es: Rosa, residente de un barrio ubicado al sur occidente de Barranquilla, emprendió su idea de negocio a partir de que su mamá quien es comerciante le propuso que vendiera a sus amigos y referidos ropa, calzado, bolsos y accesorios, fue entonces cuando Rosa empezó a ofrecer estos productos, hoy día tiene dos años en esta actividad y con una clientela fidelizada. Sus compras las realiza de contado a almacenes y distribuidores mayoristas ubicados en la ciudad de Barranquilla, por eso en la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo para invertir en la compra de ropa, calzado, bolsos y accesorios, con la finalidad de renovar los modelos e incitar a las ventas mas que todo en la temporada decembrina donde el ambiente de fiesta hace que las personas se interesen en lucir nuevos atuendos. Ella es muy comprometida con su trabajo, se dedica a esta actividad doce horas diarias, todos los días y su principal desafío es incrementar su clientela, con el fin de lograr mejores ganancias y así financiar la educación de sus dos hijos. Su meta de negocio a largo plazo es comprar vitrinas mostradoras y tener mas surtido.
texts.en:
Rosa is a resident of a neighborhood that is located in southwestern Barranquilla. She came up with a business idea that she shared with her mother, who is a merchant. Rosa proposed to sell clothes, shoes, bags, and accessories to her friends and referrals. It was then that she began offering these products and now she has been in this business for two years. She has built up a loyal clientele.

Rosa buys her merchandise with cash from stores and wholesale distributors in the city of Barranquilla. For this reason, she is applying for a Kiva loan, her first form of financing through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. She will invest in the purchase of clothes, shoes, bags, and accessories. In the end, she hopes to replenish her inventory and encourage more sales throughout the entire holiday season. The festive atmosphere makes people interested in wearing new outfits.

Rosa is very committed to her work, devoting 12 hours to her business every day. Her main challenge is increasing her clientele. In the end, she hopes to improve her earnings so that she can finance the education of her two children. Her long-term business goal is to buy display cabinets so that she can have more inventory.

loans.use: to buy clothes, shoes, bags, and accessories to sell.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a married man. He has six children. He describes himself to be determined and focused. He operates a retail business where he makes bags.

Peter has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is well served with clients and his primary customers are individuals, retailers, etc. He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy materials for making bags. His business goal is to expand business within five years. 

Peter hopes that in the future, he will educate his children. He will use the anticipated profits to educate his children and expand his business.

loans.use: to buy materials for making bags

loans.name: Hajra's Group

texts.en:
Hajra is a 30-year-old housewife. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. She is a mother of four children. Her husband owns a fruit shop in the market which is the only source of income for the family. He sells apples, bananas, and oranges from his shop. 

Presently he is interested in offering more variety to his customers, which will help him increase his net income and savings as well. However, due to a lack of money he finds it difficult. Therefore his wife Hajra has requested a loan amount from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan, so that she can help her husband to purchase a greater variety of fruits from the field to sell in the market at profitable price. 

With the profit amount, her husband wants to grow his business in the future. Hajra is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fruits for her husband's business

loans.name: Hamisu

texts.en:
Hamisu is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Hamisu would have had to sell his  maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hamisu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked about his goals, Hamisu expressed a desire to use the extra income to build a better home, and in the long run, become the most  profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Pindoty Group

texts.es:
El comité se llama Pindoty, es un grupo muy unido con 17 integrantes, se encuentran en el primer ciclo y no dudan que la ayuda que les brinda la fundación paraguaya es bastante beneficiosa, no solo para ellas, sino también para sus familias.
La Sra. Nilda es quien cumple el rol de presidenta de este comité, es muy emprendedora y se desempeña como modista, trabaja conjuntamente con una casa de confecciones de la localidad, y de esa forma tiene los medios para poder ayudar a su familia por medio de los ingresos que obtiene.
Ella pide este préstamo para poder comprar telas, hilos, botones, y demás, de manera a poder seguir con su trabajo como lo viene haciendo. Todas están muy agradecidas por la oportunidad que están recibiendo de poder crecer.
texts.en:
This committee is named “Pindoty”. It is a close-knit group that has 17 members. The group is in its first loan cycle. There is no doubt that the help provided by Fundación Paraguaya will be a great benefit, not only for the group members, but also for their families.

Sra. Nilda is fulfilling her role as the president of the committee. She is very enterprising in her job as a dressmaker. Nilda works in partnership with a sewing business in her town. This gives her the means to help her family with the income that she earns.

Nilda is requesting this loan in order to buy fabrics, thread, buttons, and other supplies so that she can continue her work just as before. All of the group members are extremely appreciative of the opportunity they have received so that they can grow.

loans.use: to buy fabrics, thread, buttons, and other supplies.

loans.name: Rima Group

texts.en:
Nadia is the featured borrower for the Rima Group. She joined with her group members to request this Al Majmoua loan because they have always been neighbors and friends. Nadia and her loan group members are working hard to develop their businesses and improve their living at the same time.
